Patch Set 27:

(1 comment)

Hi Thu, I'm sorry but unless you provide a particularly convincing argument, I can't accept this change. We instead need to convert consumers to the newer transport and instance ID APIs provided by libpldm, and eventually define an explicit requester API once we've fixed all the remaining issues.
Reducing this to -1 as there's a potential way forward that doesn't break the existing APIs.

You're simultaneously breaking the this API _and_ trying to fix the behaviour of a deprecated function. Please switch pldmtool and any other applications to use the async functions defined in the new transport API.

https://github.com/openbmc/libpldm/blob/main/include/libpldm/transport.h#L26-L79
I will remove the code changing in this API. Let discuss about pldm_transport_send_recv_msg().

Sorry, but no, that's muddling the intent of this API. This is a *transport* API, not a *requester* API. The behaviour of the transport API mustn't encode the mechanics of retries and timeouts.

Please read this blog post:

https://amboar.github.io/notes/2023/03/28/motivating-a-new-scheme-for-pldm-instance-id-management-in-openbmc.html

The requester API does not yet exist. There's a lot of work still to do, because a requester API should also abstract over the instance ID lifecycle as well as handling timeouts and retries. But we can't do that as the encode and decode functions all require instance IDs as an argument. We must fix that before we can provide a sensible requester API.

Until that's all sorted out consumers of libpldm must themselves implement a requester API by composing the transport and instance ID APIs now provided by libpldm.

Finally, again, you're breaking the API. That's not immediately acceptable - if we need to change the prototype we need to declare one with a new symbol name, otherwise we're immediately breaking all consumers. I plan to enable `abi-compliance-checker` in CI soon so I don't have to keep repeating this.

https://lvc.github.io/abi-compliance-checker/

I agree with you that we should not add retry mechanism to this API.
But about timeout, I think the API need the time out for the while loop.
I wonder how the API handle the case which there is no response from the terminus?

DSP0240 1.1.0 Table 6 defines PT3max as 6 seconds. How do you feel about exploiting that as a well-defined upper-bound without requiring new parameters to the function prototype? We don't retry, we just wait 6 seconds and then return e.g. `-ETIMEDOUT`?

As my opinion, we should use PT2 max, which mean max of "Time-out waiting for a response" for this purpose. The value of PT2max = PT3min - 2*PT4max = 4.6s. We can round that number to 5second if we want.
Updated code to use PT2max = 4800ms (please ignore my wrong value in previous mail) as response time out.
Ack
Why int?  Any reason not to do size_t?

Because the type of number-of-request-retries in https://github.com/openbmc/pldm/blob/master/meson_options.txt#L14 is int. That why I used int.
It seem the range of number-of-request-retries is 2 to 30. Let me change it to uint8_t.
This comment is no longer relevant so marking it resolved to make it disappear
Thanks, this is looking a lot better. I've added some more thoughts about how we could make the implementation less error-prone by exploiting more library functions. Let me know what you think.

I'm a bit torn here because `timespec_get()` is defined by C but I'm concerned that because we're passing `TIME_UTC` (the only defined time base?) that we're leaving ourselves open to hangs or early exits from changes to wall-clock time (e.g. chronyd syncing the time).

I'm wondering if we're better off depending on `clock_gettime()` (defined by POSIX) and using `CLOCK_MONOTONIC`? `CLOCK_MONOTONIC` is guaranteed not to shift with changes to wall clock time. As it is just an implementation detail, for freestanding environments we can substitute use of `clock_gettime()` with something else without affecting the public API.

Also see the discussion below.
Thank for you info. I tried to study about the difference between clock_gettime and timespec_get. It seem clock_gettime is widely used than timespec_get and clock_gettime is better.
I updated code after studying about clock_gettime().
Done

Can we define this in `src/transport/transport.c` instead? I don't think we need visibility of this macro outside the C file at the moment (I realise this is an internal header, but all the same).

In fact, with some of the discussion I added in the implementation we may be able to do away with this macro.
Updated.
Added the commit title to Fixed section of CHANGELog.md and add "transport:" to commit title.
Nice! Thanks.
Ack
I might have miscounted the 0's but I read this as 8,000,000 us which is 8000 ms. Don't we want 800?
Updated.
Would this `rc` be lost if `pldm_transport_recv_msg` failed, since we are using the same variable for `clock_gettimeval`.

Also it seems that on hitting error with `pldm_transport_recv_msg`, the loop will be iterated with calls to `pldm_transport_poll/pldm_transport_recv_msg` if nowval < endval. It will break from the loop eventually and rc will be `-ETIMEDOUT`.
+1. Although I'm not sure what's more important to propagate, why `pldm_transport_recv_msg` failed (if it did) or that we timed out before getting a valid response message...
+1. Maybe we give `pldm_transport_recv_msg` it's own return code that
(ignore my first message!)

Checking time out is just an addition condition to exit the while if the errors happen. The API should ignore the error of clock_gettimeval() ( I don't think we have error in call clock_gettimeval() ) and focus on the return code of pldm_transport_recv_msg and pldm_transport_poll() in the while loop.
We're resolving the error handling as part of reworking the loop behaviour.
From the logic, it seems errors
Ignore, hit Enter before completing.
I would
Oops, I forgot to delete my drafts!
Add my thought above.
If `clock_gettimeval()` errors then we potentially don't update `nowval`, and we loop infinitely. That's the opposite of the intention of this patch. We need to exit the loop on error.

It is just our choice for below case:
The time out is 4800ms, the clock_gettimeval() has error at 2500ms, and the API will get the response from the terminus at 3500ms. What will we want?
For the current code, I expected that the while loop will bypass the error at 2500ms and then response the PLDM response data at 3500ms.
Because as my opinion, the error or response data from PLDM message have higher priority. Moreover the rate of continuous failure in calling clock_gettimeval() is very very low. So the change to API loop forever because failure in clock_gettimeval() is very low.
The purpose of this patch set is catch the case which the pldm_transport_recv_msg() always response error but not clock_gettimeval().

Sure, but if anything I think that highlights an extra problem we have here, which is that we're always calling `pldm_transport_poll()` with the fixed constant `PLDM_MAX_RESPONSE_TIMEOUT`. If we make two calls we're potentially waiting just short of `2 * PLDM_MAX_RESPONSE_TIMEOUT` in total. What we instead want is that for any number of calls to `pldm_transport_poll()` the time between the start of the first call and the end of the last call doesn't exceed `PLDM_MAX_RESPONSE_TIME`. The value that we pass to `pldm_transport_poll` has to be derived from `nowval` and `endval` to uphold the desired behaviour. Which means that any failure of `clock_gettimeval()` has to be honoured (otherwise we'll be passing the wrong interval value).
I understand now. Updated the code.
I've suggested an implementation I think has the desired properties.
Can you please append the time unit to the symbol? `PLDM_MAX_RESPONSE_TIME_OUT_MS`
With new code change. The constant is un-used. So I removed it.
Given we're not mixing `struct timeval` and `struct timespec` at all we can probably drop the `val` suffix` from `nowval` and `endval`
Updated.
This is a bit of a nitpick, but I'd prefer we order `static const` variable declarations before mutable variable declarations.
Updated.
Oh, the return value must be one of the `PLDM_REQUESTER_*` constants, we mustn't be inconsistent here. Sorry, just noticed this.
I think PLDM_REQUESTER_RECV_FAIL and PLDM_REQUESTER_POLL_FAIL is potential options.
I'd probably go with `PLDM_REQUESTER_POLL_FAIL`.
Updated.

This doesn't fix the upper bound issue I mentioned in PS14. We're still passing a constant through to `pldm_transport_poll()` on line 161 and that will allow us to exceed the timeout upper bound quite significantly if we take multiple trips through the loop.

Further if we break here we return the `rc` value provided by `pldm_transport_recv_msg()` which may be unrelated to a failure of `clock_gettimeval()`. We should be clear about what caused the failure. The success of the `clock_gettimeval()` call is essential to the correct operation of the loop, and if it doesn't succeed we can't meet the timing guarantee we're trying to provide. We should pick an appropriate `PLDM_REQUESTER_*` constant to return.

I think we can send PT1 + 2*PT4 = 300ms to pldm_transport_poll() as "Table 6: Timing specifications for PLDM messages" in DSP0240
So we can reduce the exceed time from 4800ms to 300ms. The bias 6.25% with the expected time out is acceptable also.
Updated.
Done
Hi Thu, a couple of minor cleanups and this should be good to go. The redundant validation of `end` is the main concern.

A nitpick that I think we can resolve given the other issue with validation below: There's a silly inconsistency between the names of `struct timeval` and the `timer*()` functions. I think I'd prefer the name to be in terms of the struct here and not get ourselves confused in the extra `r` business. It would be nice to rename this to `timeval_to_msec()` without the `r`. Apologies if I got that wrong in my comment where I defined this function.
Updated.
Nit: As above, let's drop the `r` and use `timeval_is_valid()`.
Updated.

We don't need to revalidate here because end doesn't change after its initial derivation on line 182. The trick was that we only needed to validate once and all future calls to `timeval_to_msec()` are known not to overflow.
Sorry for my mistake, I would like to check the valid of "remaining", because timersub does not have return value just as we do with "end" in timeradd.
Done
Some type issues have crept in with the latest patchset, and I've also provided some justification about why `timeval_is_valid(&remaining)` is redundant.

Are you doing the cast to int here so the types line up for `pldm_transport_poll()`? If so, we shouldn't be mixing abstractions that way. The cast should be at the call-site, not in the implementation. Let's keep a proper separation of concerns.

Please keep this as returning a `long`.
Done
Given that the outcome of `timeval_is_valid()` is either "yes it's valid" or "no it's not valid" I think we should just make it return a `bool`.
Done

`timeval_is_valid()` protects `timeval_to_msec()` from overflow. If `time_to_msec()` is changed to returning `int`, then this needed to be changed to `INT_MAX`.

But as mentioned above the types should remain as `long`.
Done
Done

This check is still unnecessary because we know the calculations won't overflow for `end`.

A few facts are relevant:

1. We're using `CLOCK_MONOTONIC` which will never decrease in value (even if the system time is changed)
2. We derive `end` from `now` by adding an interval
3. We're validating `end` for millisecond conversion overflow after adding the interval
4. We're subtracting `now` from `end` to derive `remaining`, which yields the initial interval the first time through the loop.

At this point `remaining` must be positive as `now` is less than `end`. If `end` can be safely converted to milliseconds without overflow then it holds that `now` and `remaining` may also be safely converted without further checks.

Now we have to deal with the loop condition:

1. Prior to testing the loop condition we update `now` to the current time
2. The loop terminates if `now` is equal to or exceeds `end`

Assume the loop condition evaluates to `false`. `now` is not less than `end` and we exit without recalculating `remaining`. There's no risk of overflow as there's no subsequent conversion of `remaining` to milliseconds via `timeval_to_msec()`.

Now assume the loop conditions evaluates to `true`. `now` must be strictly less than `end`. The derivation of `remaining` is `end - now`, which must be a positive interval with a value less than `end`. If the conversion of `end` to milliseconds cannot overflow, it remains the case that `remaining` cannot overflow either.

Therefore it is redundant to call `timeval_is_valid(&remaining)` in the loop. We know that it must be valid by the success of `timeval_is_valid(&end)` on line 183.

So, I'd prefer we remove this check. If it remains in the code its presence becomes a point of confusion: people will have to re-prove all this to make sure that it is in fact redundant.
Done

Given the discussion about keeping the return type as `long` above, this will become:

```
/* 0 <= `timeval_to_msec()` <= 4800000, and 4800000 < INT_MAX */
rc = pldm_transport_poll(transport, (int)(timeval_to_msec(&remaining)));
```

While C specifies `INT_MAX` as not less than 16-bit signed max, the practical reality tells us:

```
2 09:26:58 andrew@fedora:~$ \
> for a in aarch64 arm powerpc64le riscv64 x86_64; \
> do \
>    echo $a; \
>    ${a}-linux-gnu-gcc -E -dM -x c - <<<'#include <limits.h>' |
>        grep __INT_MAX__; \
>    echo; \
> done
aarch64
#define INT_MAX __INT_MAX__
#define __INT_MAX__ 0x7fffffff

arm
#define INT_MAX __INT_MAX__
#define __INT_MAX__ 0x7fffffff

powerpc64le
#define __INT_MAX__ 0x7fffffff
#define INT_MAX __INT_MAX__

riscv64
#define INT_MAX __INT_MAX__
#define __INT_MAX__ 0x7fffffff

x86_64
#define INT_MAX __INT_MAX__
#define __INT_MAX__ 0x7fffffff
```
Done
quick, while you're fixing the build!
Sorry, I got this comment wrong; it should have `4800` (milliseconds) not `4800000` (microseconds).
Done
Any unit tests applicable for this patch?
It would be nice to have a dummy transport implementation so we can test these kind of things, but I figured Thu had been through too much on this patch already to also ask for that.
For these kind of code, I think checking the code logic is enough. I'm testing this code with my systems.

Tested the patch set #25 with Ampere system.
The code work as expected.
Thanks for persisting with this patch across the feedback 😊

> tv->tv_usec >= 1000000

Ugh, of course it doesn't behave like `strcmp()` 😕 Also I failed at reading comprehension.

>        timercmp()  compares the timer values in a and b using the comparison
>        operator CMP, and returns true (nonzero) or false (0) depending on the
>        result of the comparison.  Some systems (but not Linux/glibc), have a
>        broken timercmp() implementation, in which CMP of >=, <=, and == do not
>        work; portable applications can instead use
>
>           !timercmp(..., <)
>           !timercmp(..., >)
>           !timercmp(..., !=)
